title: How to be more empathetic

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the primary difference between empathy and sympathy?

options.label: A
options.text: Empathy is about feeling sorry for someone, while sympathy is about feeling with someone.

options.label: B
options.text: Empathy is about feeling with someone, while sympathy is about feeling sorry for someone.

options.label: C
options.text: Empathy is about taking action to help someone, while sympathy is about offering words of comfort.

options.label: D
options.text: Empathy is about understanding someone's perspective, while sympathy is about ignoring someone's perspective.

multiple-choice.question: What are the four qualities of empathy identified by Theresa Wiseman?

options.label: A
options.text: Perspective taking, staying out of judgment, recognizing emotion, and offering solutions.

options.label: B
options.text: Perspective taking, staying out of judgment, recognizing emotion, and communicating that emotion.

options.label: C
options.text: Perspective taking, making assumptions, recognizing emotion, and offering sympathy.

options.label: D
options.text: Perspective taking, staying out of judgment, ignoring emotion, and communicating that emotion.

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is a common mistake people make when trying to respond to someone who has shared something difficult?

options.label: A
options.text: They try to offer too much advice.

options.label: B
options.text: They try to make things better by offering a silver lining.

options.label: C
options.text: They try to change the subject.

options.label: D
options.text: They try to ignore the person's feelings.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's suggestion for how to respond to someone who has shared something difficult?

options.label: A
options.text: Try to offer a solution to the problem.

options.label: B
options.text: Try to make things better by offering a silver lining.

options.label: C
options.text: Say something like, "I don't even know what to say. I'm just so glad you told me."

options.label: D
options.text: Try to change the subject.

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what makes something better in the face of a difficult conversation?

options.label: A
options.text: A response that offers a solution.

options.label: B
options.text: A response that tries to make things better.

options.label: C
options.text: Connection with the person.

options.label: D
options.text: Ignoring the person's feelings.

title: How to be confident

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is one of the consequences of being too attached to our own dignity?

options.label: A
options.text: We become more confident in our abilities.

options.label: B
options.text: We are more likely to take risks and try new things.

options.label: C
options.text: We hold back from challenges in which there is any risk of ending up looking ridiculous.

options.label: D
options.text: We become more arrogant and dismissive of others.

multiple-choice.question: What is the central argument of Erasmus' book "In Praise of Folly"?

options.label: A
options.text: That it is possible to lead a good life without making mistakes.

options.label: B
options.text: That everyone, regardless of their importance or learning, is a fool.

options.label: C
options.text: That it is essential to maintain a dignified image at all times.

options.label: D
options.text: That making mistakes is a sign of weakness.

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the message of Pieter Brueghel's work "The Dutch Proverbs"?

options.label: A
options.text: That human nature is inherently wise and rational.

options.label: B
options.text: That some people are more foolish than others.

options.label: C
options.text: That everyone is pretty much deranged and prone to making mistakes.

options.label: D
options.text: That it is possible to avoid making mistakes through careful planning.

multiple-choice.question: What is the proposed solution to gaining greater confidence, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: To reassure ourselves of our own dignity and importance.

options.label: B
options.text: To grow at peace with the inevitable nature of our ridiculousness.

options.label: C
options.text: To avoid taking risks and trying new things.

options.label: D
options.text: To become more arrogant and dismissive of others.

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the suggested ritual for gaining greater confidence?

options.label: A
options.text: To tell oneself that one is capable and competent.

options.label: B
options.text: To remind oneself of past successes and achievements.

options.label: C
options.text: To tell oneself that one is a muttonhead, a cretin, a dumbbell, and an imbecile.

options.label: D
options.text: To visualize oneself achieving great things.

options.label: C

options.label: B

options.label: D

title: Why we should draw more (and photograph less)

options.label: B
options.text: We are likely to be so busy taking pictures that we forget to look at the world around us.

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: We are likely to take poor-quality pictures.

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.text: They will take a lot of pictures to remember the scene.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main point of Ruskin's passage about the two individuals walking down a green lane?

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

title: Why 350°F is the magic number for baking

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary purpose of preheating an oven to 350 degrees Fahrenheit in baking?

options.label: A
options.text: To control the moisture in the product

options.label: B
options.text: To develop color and flavor in the product

options.label: C
options.text: To initiate the Maillard reaction

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

multiple-choice.question: What is the Maillard reaction, and what occurs during this process?

options.label: A
options.text: A chemical process where proteins and sugars are transformed by heat and moisture, resulting in browning and flavor development

options.label: B
options.text: A physical process where sugar molecules are reduced and interact with proteins, resulting in a golden crust

options.label: C
options.text: A biological process where yeast ferments and produces carbon dioxide, resulting in a lighter texture

options.label: D
options.text: A thermal process where heat is transferred from the oven to the product, resulting in a crispy exterior

multiple-choice.question: According to Michael Laiskonis, what temperature range does the Maillard reaction typically occur at?

options.label: A
options.text: 200-250 degrees Fahrenheit

options.label: B
options.text: 230-240 degrees Fahrenheit

options.label: C
options.text: 300-350 degrees Fahrenheit

options.label: D
options.text: 400-450 degrees Fahrenheit

multiple-choice.question: Why do recipe writers often specify 350 degrees Fahrenheit as the standard temperature for baking?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it is the optimal temperature for the Maillard reaction to occur

options.label: B
options.text: Because it is a safe standard for most people, taking into account variations in oven temperature

options.label: C
options.text: Because it is the temperature at which sugar molecules start to reduce and interact with proteins

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is the temperature at which yeast ferments and produces carbon dioxide

options.label: C
options.text: Using a timer to control the baking time

options.label: D
options.text: Relying on instinct and experience to determine the optimal temperature

title: Why do we eat spoiled food?

What is the primary reason why our ancestors developed a natural repulsion to certain foods?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they were allergic to certain ingredients

options.label: B
options.text: Because they were concerned about the nutritional value

options.label: C
options.text: Because they associated certain foods with nasty germs

options.label: D
options.text: Because they were worried about the environmental impact

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: To outcompete pathogens and keep the meat safe

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: To change the texture of the bread

options.label: D

options.label: B

title: Systemic racism explained

multiple-choice.question: Why is Jamal's school not well-funded compared to Kevin's school?

options.label: A
options.text: Because Jamal's school has fewer students.

options.label: B
options.text: Because Jamal's school district is mostly funded by property taxes, which are lower in his neighborhood.

options.label: C
options.text: Because Jamal's school has less experienced teachers.

options.label: D
options.text: Because Jamal's school has fewer extracurricular activities.

multiple-choice.question: What was the practice of "redlining" in the context of systemic racism?

options.label: A
options.text: It was a practice of dividing cities into sections that were either desirable or undesirable for investment based on socioeconomic status.

options.label: B
options.text: It was a practice of dividing cities into sections that were either desirable or undesirable for investment based on racial demographics.

options.label: C
options.text: It was a practice of providing low-interest loans to African American families.

options.label: D
options.text: It was a practice of promoting diversity in neighborhoods.

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the result of systemic racism in terms of wealth disparity between white and black families?

options.label: A
options.text: For every $100 of wealth held by a white family, black families have $50.

options.label: B
options.text: For every $100 of wealth held by a white family, black families have $20.

options.label: C
options.text: For every $100 of wealth held by a white family, black families have $5.04.

options.label: D
options.text: For every $100 of wealth held by a white family, black families have $1.

multiple-choice.question: What is "implicit bias" in the context of systemic racism?

options.label: A
options.text: It refers to prejudices in society that people are aware of and actively promote.

options.label: B
options.text: It refers to prejudices in society that people are not aware that they have.

options.label: C
options.text: It refers to the practice of redlining.

options.label: D
options.text: It refers to the wealth disparity between white and black families.

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is one way to address systemic racism?

options.label: A
options.text: By increasing public school funding and making it dependent on property taxes.

options.label: B
options.text: By increasing public school funding and making it independent from property taxes.

options.label: C
options.text: By promoting diversity in neighborhoods.

options.label: D
options.text: By providing low-interest loans to African American families.

title: The taxonomy of candy

options.label: A
options.text: To group organisms based on their physical characteristics

options.label: B
options.text: To bring out the evolutionary relationships between organisms

options.label: C
options.text: To classify organisms based on their colors

options.label: D
options.text: To categorize organisms based on their habitats

options.label: A
options.text: As different species within the same genus

options.label: B
options.text: As different genera within the same family

options.label: C
options.text: As different families within the same order

options.label: D
options.text: As different orders within the same class

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: They are not all the same size

options.label: C
options.text: They are not all related to each other

options.label: D
options.text: They are not all the same color intensity

multiple-choice.question: According to Larry, what makes organisms different from candy in terms of classification?

options.label: A
options.text: Organisms are classified based on their colors, while candy is classified based on its shape

options.label: B
options.text: Organisms are classified based on their relationships and ancestors, while candy can be classified in any way

options.label: C
options.text: Organisms are classified based on their habitats, while candy is classified based on its taste

options.label: D
options.text: Organisms are classified based on their sizes, while candy is classified based on its texture

multiple-choice.question: What is the philosophical question raised by Olivier at the end of the conversation?

options.label: A
options.text: Is it possible to classify all living things into a single system?

options.label: B
options.text: Is it us bringing order to the world, or does the world come to us in an ordered way?

options.label: C

options.label: D

title: What is echolocation?

options.label: B
options.text: Using their sense of sight

options.label: C
options.text: Using echolocation, a combination of voice, ears, and echoes

options.label: D
options.text: Using their sense of touch

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: 50-50,000 waves per second

options.label: D
options.text: 100-100,000 waves per second

title: The most horrifying parasites on the planet
